To come to the 9% forecast, I applied H (hunt for the right information) and K (know the key players who can influence the market) from CHAMPS KNOW. Hunting for the right information, I began with the simple statement made by the Russian government: “We do not see any possibility to take part in the preparations for the Fourth Summit on Nuclear Security.” Russia is known to be controversial in many of their views, so I started at what I consider a high 20% likelihood based on this statement alone. After some more research, it became clear that Russia sent their foreign minister to attend in 2014, and since then Russia has stated no new agenda items have come up that would instill a desire to participate. Looking further back at these summits, Putin has never actually attended, leading no reason to believe he would attend this year. Combined with Putin’s hothead personality who doesn’t go back on statements, I reduced the forecast to 6%. In reasoning, however, I also looked to other key players who can influence this decision in the opposite direction. Specifically, North Korea recently tested a hydrogen bomb. Because of Putin’s proximity to North Korea and the global concern with their tactics, he might feel compelled to attend the summit and play a dominating role about how to curb North Korea (likely with some underlying political interests here). Because of this possibility, I slightly adjusted the likelihood of attendance upwards to 9%.

To forecast this question, I first asked if Putin has ever visited Japan. The answer to this question is no. Based on Putin's track record of never visiting Japan, my probabilistic estimate of Putin visiting Japan before 1 July 2016 would be fairly low - I would give it 20 to 1 odds, or 5%.   Next, I asked myself if Putin has  publicly announced any intentions of visiting Japan. Surprisingly, the answer to this question is yes. Putin agreed several months ago to visit Japan. However, no date was set for the meeting. Based on this information, I would increase my odds from 20 to 1 to 2 to 1 or 50%.  Based on this information, I asked myself what the REASON for the meeting between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Putin would be. The answer to this question is that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wishes to negotiate the "Northern Territories Dispute" (http://www.ibtimes.com/japans-shinzo-abe-calls-summit-russias-vladimir-putin-over-northern-territories-2247350). This dispute is over islands that were annexed by Soviet forces during the Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation after the end of World War II. The San Francisco Peace Treaty with Japan from 1951 states that Japan must give up all claims to the Kuril Islands, but it also does not recognize the Soviet Union's sovereignty over the Kuril Islands.  Thus, Japan is basically saying "Hey, I know that the US said that we can't have these islands and we know you have them now, but we still want them. So can we please have them if we ask really nicely? Pretty please???" Putin has a track record of 1) being a tough guy, and 2) trying to expand Russia (think Crimea). I heard Japan's Prime Minister speak at Harvard last year, he's a smart guy but he is not going to negotiate these islands away from Putin. Thus, I suspect that a meeting between the two leaders will be for public show more than anything.  Having studied Putin's leadership style, I know that Putin is going to want to have the balance of power tilted in his direction on any negotiations over these islands. This is why he is getting the Japanese Prime Minister to meet with him in Russia this spring (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-g20-turkey-russia-japan-idUSKCN0T518F20151116). Putin wants to negotiate on his own turf where he has more power in the negotiation.  After the meeting in Russia, I suspect that Putin will continue to postpone his visit to Japan until the trip is forgotten. This is a typical Russian political tactic.  In conclusion: 1. Putin has never visited Japan.
2. Putin has agreed to visit Japan, but has not set a specific date.
3. Putin has very little to gain from a visit to Japan.
4. Putin wants to meet on his own turf, where he has more power in a negotiation. 
5. The two parties will meet in Russia this Spring.
6. The chances of the two leaders meeting again before 1 July 2016 in Japan is very low. Based on this information, I would estimate the chances of the two parties meeting again before the 1st of July (this time on Japanese soil) to be fairly low, probably around 12%.

10-Dec-2015: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is planning to visit Russia next spring for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Kyodo news reported on Dec. 10, citing diplomatic sources. The talks would focus on the Southern Kuril territorial dispute, according to the report. The beginning of arrangements for such a trip is in response to an invitation extended to Abe by Putin to visit a local city in Russia other than Moscow, when the two leaders held talks in November, the news agency, cited its sources as saying. Russia and Japan will begin preparations for Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s 2016 visit to a Russian region with deputy foreign minister-level talks in February 2016, NHK news reported on Dec. 30. Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Morgulov and his Japanese counterpart Shinsuke Sugiyama will discuss Abe’s visit at a meeting in Moscow in February, according to the report. 4-January-2016: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for a summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin to resolve ongoing territorial disputes between the two countries. 19-Jan-2016: Abe also said that “as the chair of the G7” he would consider a visit to Russia “at the appropriate time”, which the Nikkei newspaper interpreted as meaning ahead of the G7 summit in May. I ran the translation from @Dima-K article through Google.  A copy is below.  The caption states, "Japan is considering the question of Putin's visit in July." I also went through a few upcoming political and sporting events.  A timeline with thoughts:   Early spring:  
Abe to Russia.  We already have multiple posts here, of the possible Abe Visit to Russia in the first half of 2016. As for Putin reciprocating, I can see him traveling in late July, as very likely. This is because...  Late April - May: 
The 42nd G7 Summit, hosted by Abe, will be held in Japan at the end of May 2016.  RU has not been invited back into the group. Abe will be likely, be quite involved, organizing G7 details during this time.  There is the possibility of bundling Putin in at this time, but political tensions from the G7 and the upcoming UN meeting in June, would be present. It is also probably too soon for Putin-Abe to do a follow up meeting late spring - early summer. I also believe both parties want their meetings to stand independent from all other events, until they near a resolution.  June:
The UN Security Council is meeting in late June. Big elections. Plus many will be lobbying for Ban Ki Moon's position (ending 31 Dec 2016) at this meeting. Putin will attend.  July: 
Russia is hosting the 7th Annual BRICS Summit in early July.  In the months leading up to July, there will be plenty of time to plan for another meeting. So... Abe hosting Putin later this month is a possibility.    August:
Since 2000, Putin has traveled outside Russia five times during this month.  Two of those visits were to the Olympics. Putin often (very often) bundles state meetings around big sporting events.  This year, Putin will be alongside Rousseff at the Olympics to hand the flag over to the Rio mayor.  He is also scheduled to meet with Rousseff during this visit.  In short, Putin will be busy in Brazil.  September-October:
The G20 meets early this month. Abe and Putin will attend. A side meeting could happen here, or, another Abe-Putin meeting could happen soon after. North Korea's Party Foundation Day happens in early October. Putin has traveled to NK in autumn. Their relationship could factor in to an Abe-Putin meeting at this time.  December:
Russia hosts the World Cup in 2018 meaning Putin (highly involved in the process already) will be in Japan in December to watch enjoy the event as well as oversee how the event is organized and run. Another meeting, or, even a possible (but highly unlikely) celebratory conclusion to previous meetings, could take place around the FIFA event. Russia has increased the frequency and scale of military exercises in and around its northern territories. As demonstrated in events in which Russian fighter jets soared over the Sea of Okhotsk, Putin is asserting Russian dominance over diplomatic malleability and a willingness to negotiate. On Sept 16, a Russian plane was identified as having entered Japanese airspace off the coast of Hokkaido by defense officials, and was shortly intercepted by four Japanese fighter jets. These aggressive displays of military bravado are, according to the former deputy director of future operations for the U.S. Navy’s Fifth Fleet, akin to “a tiger showing its teeth.”   The detainment of 11 Hokkaido-based Japanese fishermen by Russian authorities for operating within Russia’s claimed territorial waters also exemplifies the difficult circumstances that prohibit a swift resolution to the Kuril Islands dispute. While this issue didn’t appear to create much political blowback, similar future incidents could seriously harm relations. More troubling than this is the Russian government’s recent announcement to develop a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in the Russian Far East — which included the disputed islands. Between 2016 and 2025, Russia plans on attracting foreign investment from China and South Korea with the aim of developing the region economically. The use of Chinese and Korean money would no doubt be viewed suspiciously by Japan.   Perhaps more problematic to Japan than Russia’s increasing military presence in the region, however, is the fact that its ties with China are steadily improving. China’s military rise and posture toward Japan has generated several “concerns” from the Japanese government. Russia previously sought to limit China from procuring more advanced arms, but within the past year it has changed its stance, agreeing to export its S-400 surface-to-air missile system to the Chinese who will become the first foreign buyer of the advanced system.

The row blocked a peace treaty between Russia and Japan after World War Two.

Japan protested when Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev visited Kunashir and Iturup in August. The Kurils are called the Northern Territories in Japan.
